Detailed analyses

title: Detailed analyses
text:
On this page, I lay out in more technical detail the analysis of the student anxiety data using MASS::polr().
I also (very) briefly illustrate two other widespread ways of analysing ordinal data: treating it as continuous numeric data and using a Gaussian model, and first converting it to z-scores by participant and then using a Gaussian model on those z-scores.

title: Detailed analyses
text:
Footnotes


Terry, J., Ross, R. M., Nagy, T., Salgado, M., Garrido-V√°squez, P., Sarfo, J. O., Cooper, S., Buttner, A. C., Lima, T. J. S., √ñzt√ºrk, ƒ∞., Akay, N., Santos, F. H., Artemenko, C., Copping, L. T., Elsherif, M. M., Milovanoviƒá, I., Cribbie, R. A., Drushlyak, M. G., Swainston, K., ‚Ä¶ Field, A. P. (2023). Data from an International Multi-Centre Study of Statistics and Mathematics Anxieties and Related Variables in University Students (the SMARVUS Dataset). Journal of Open Psychology Data, 11(1), 8.‚Ü©Ô∏é
In the teaching presentation materials, I replaced 1‚Äì5 with A‚ÄìE, but for the present analyses, I‚Äôll leave the original digits as labels for each rating level.‚Ü©Ô∏é
 If I had used method = "logit", then the model would assume not a normal distribution but a logistic distribution. Similar shape, but different scale, so (back)transformation between the model space and probability space would happen not with pnorm()/qnorm() but with plogis()/qlogis().‚Ü©Ô∏é
 Ideally we‚Äôd be comparing t-values to a t distribution. But the t distribution approximates the normal distribution increasingly well with increasing degrees of freedom, and degrees of freedom increase with larger sample sizes. And we‚Äôve got a lot of data in this analysis, so I‚Äôm not too worried about poorly approximating the H0 distribution.‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Detailed analyses
text:
Intercept-only model

Look at the data
Here‚Äôs the pattern of participant responses overall to the scenario ‚ÄúGoing to ask my statistics teacher for individual help with material I am having difficulty understanding‚Äù.

anx |>
  ggplot(aes(x = factor(rating))) +
  geom_bar(fill = '#2e3836') +
  labs(
    x = element_blank(),
    y = 'Count',
    caption = 'n = 8,314'
  ) +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c('1\n(no anxiety)', '2', '3', '4', '5\n(a great deal\nof anxiety)')) +
  NULL










Fit the model
To use polr(), the outcome variable must be a factor. There‚Äôs no need to manually specify the order of levels, since they‚Äôre already in the correct order by default.2

anx <- anx |>
  mutate(rating = factor(rating))

anx_fit1 <- polr(
  rating ~ 1,
  data = anx,
  method = 'probit',
  Hess = TRUE  # set TRUE if want to use summary()
)

summary(anx_fit1)

Call:
polr(formula = rating ~ 1, data = anx, Hess = TRUE, method = "probit")

No coefficients

Intercepts:
    Value    Std. Error t value 
1|2  -0.8420   0.0157   -53.7268
2|3  -0.1678   0.0138   -12.1462
3|4   0.3833   0.0141    27.1512
4|5   1.0339   0.0168    61.6193

Residual Deviance: 26596.28 
AIC: 26604.28 




Interpret the model
The values estimated for the Intercepts aren‚Äôt really intercepts, not like the intercept of a linear model. Rather, these values represent the thresholds (also called cutpoints) along a continuous latent variable. This latent variable is a construct which the model assumes to represent some continuous measure of anxiety. Sometimes you‚Äôll see this assumed latent variable represented as \(\Phi\) (phi), and sometimes those thresholds will be represented as \(\zeta\) (zeta).
We can extract the threshold values as follows:

anx_fit1$zeta

       1|2        2|3        3|4        4|5 
-0.8419663 -0.1678099  0.3833389  1.0339047 


Because I‚Äôve used the probit link (by specifying method = "probit"), the model further assumes that anxiety follows a standard normal distribution over this continuous latent variable.3 A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1.

rating_labs1 <- tibble(
  x = c(-2.6, -1.2, -0.5, 0.1, 0.7, 1.3),
  d = c(0.47),
  labs = c('Rating:', 1:5)
)

p_underlying_normal <- tibble(x = seq(from = -3.5, to = 3.5, length.out = 200)) |> 
  mutate(d = dnorm(x = x)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = x, y = d)) +
  geom_area(fill = '#2e3836', alpha = 0.4) +
  geom_text(data = rating_labs1, aes(label = labs), family = "Fira Sans", size = 8) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = anx_fit1$zeta, linetype = 'dotted', linewidth = 1) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    'Anxiety (assumed latent variable)',
    breaks = -3:3,
    sec.axis = dup_axis(
      name = NULL,
      breaks = anx_fit1$zeta |> as.double(),
      labels = round(anx_fit1$zeta, 2)
    )
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    NULL, 
    breaks = NULL,
    limits = c(0, 0.5)
    ) +
  theme( 
    axis.line.x.top = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x.top = element_blank()
  ) +
  NULL

p_underlying_normal








Having defined this normal distribution allows us to compute the probability density within each region delineated by the thresholds. One way to do this is using pnorm(). The default usage of pnorm() tells us, for a standard normal distribution, how much probability density falls to the left of the given value. For the intermediate regions, we subtract the probability density below the region‚Äôs leftward periphery from the probability density below its rightward periphery, to get only the density between those two bounds.

(anx_fit1_p1 <- pnorm(-0.84))                  # probability of rating 1

[1] 0.2004542

(anx_fit1_p2 <- pnorm(-0.17) - pnorm(-0.84))   # probability of rating 2

[1] 0.2320509

(anx_fit1_p3 <- pnorm(0.38) - pnorm(-0.17))    # probability of rating 3

[1] 0.2155222

(anx_fit1_p4 <- pnorm(1.03) - pnorm(0.38))     # probability of rating 4

[1] 0.2004677

(anx_fit1_p5 <- pnorm(1000) - pnorm(1.03))     # probability of rating 5

[1] 0.151505


(For rating 5, I just grabbed some huge value as an arbitrary upper bound. The outcome is essentially the same for upper bounds of 10, 100, 1000‚Ä¶)
A good sense check: these probabilities approximate the overall proportion of responses to each rating in the original data.

table(anx$rating) / nrow(anx)


        1         2         3         4         5 
0.1999038 0.2334616 0.2159009 0.2001443 0.1505894 


Here‚Äôs one way to visualise the probability density within each region of the distribution.

anx_fit1_probs <- c(anx_fit1_p1, anx_fit1_p2, anx_fit1_p3, anx_fit1_p4, anx_fit1_p5)

prob_labs1 <- tibble(
  x = c(-2.6, -1.2, -0.5, 0.1, 0.7, 1.3),
  d = c(0.1),
  labs = c('Probability:', round(anx_fit1_probs, 2))
)

p_underlying_normal +
  geom_text(data = prob_labs1, aes(label = labs), family = "Fira Sans")

title: Detailed analyses
text:
Modelling ratings by gender

Look at the data


Fit the model


Interpret the model

title: Detailed analyses
text:
Fit the model
To use polr(), the outcome variable must be a factor. No need to manually specify the order of levels, since the numeric labelling ensures they‚Äôre in the correct order by default.

anx <- anx |>
  mutate(rating = factor(rating))

I begin by fitting an intercept-only model to this data.

anx_fit1 <- polr(
  rating ~ 1,
  data = anx,
  method = 'probit',
  Hess = TRUE  # set TRUE if want to use summary()
)

summary(anx_fit1)

Call:
polr(formula = rating ~ 1, data = anx, Hess = TRUE, method = "probit")

No coefficients

Intercepts:
    Value    Std. Error t value 
1|2  -0.8420   0.0157   -53.7268
2|3  -0.1678   0.0138   -12.1462
3|4   0.3833   0.0141    27.1512
4|5   1.0339   0.0168    61.6193

Residual Deviance: 26596.28 
AIC: 26604.28 


The values estimated for the Intercepts aren‚Äôt really intercepts, not like in a linear model. Rather, they represent the thresholds (also called cutpoints) along a continuous latent variable, a construct which the model assumes to represent some continuous measure of anxiety.
Because I‚Äôve used the probit link function in method = "probit", the model further assumes that anxiety is normally distributed over this continuous latent variable. (If I had used method = "logit", then the model would use not a normal distribution but a logistic distribution.)

title: Detailed analyses
text:
rating ~ gender

Look at the data
I first converted gender to a factor. I set Female/Woman as the first level (important for the treatment coding I‚Äôll use below), followed by Male/Man and Another Gender.

anx <- anx |>
  mutate(gender = factor(gender, levels = c('Female/Woman', 'Male/Man', 'Another Gender')))

Here are participants‚Äô anxiety ratings for the same question as above, now divided by their gender:

anx |>
  ggplot(aes(x = rating, fill = gender)) +
  geom_bar() +
  facet_wrap(~ gender, scales = 'free', nrow=3) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = palette_gender) +
  labs(
    x = element_blank(),
    y = 'Count'
  ) +
  theme(legend.position = 'none') +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c('1\n(no anxiety)', '2', '3', '4', '5\n(a great deal\nof anxiety)')) +
  NULL








(Yikes, right? üòû)


Fit the model
I used R‚Äôs default treatment coding for gender. Because of the level ordering I specified above for gender, Female/Woman will be the reference level, and we‚Äôll get two dummy variables: one comparing Female/Woman to Male/Man, and one comparing Female/Woman to Another Gender. To confirm, here‚Äôs the contrast matrix:

contrasts(anx$gender)

               Male/Man Another Gender
Female/Woman          0              0
Male/Man              1              0
Another Gender        0              1


Fit the model:

anx_fit2 <- polr(
  rating ~ gender,
  data = anx,
  method = 'probit',
  Hess = TRUE
)

summary(anx_fit2)

Call:
polr(formula = rating ~ gender, data = anx, Hess = TRUE, method = "probit")

Coefficients:
                       Value Std. Error t value
genderMale/Man       -0.3280    0.03015 -10.880
genderAnother Gender  0.4846    0.11992   4.041

Intercepts:
    Value    Std. Error t value 
1|2  -0.9045   0.0169   -53.5402
2|3  -0.2246   0.0150   -14.9847
3|4   0.3318   0.0151    21.9158
4|5   0.9889   0.0176    56.2958

Residual Deviance: 26456.99 
AIC: 26468.99 




Interpret the model
Just as the Intercepts aren‚Äôt the intercept of a line, the Coefficients are not the slope of a line. Rather, they give the mean of the normal distribution that represents how each gender group‚Äôs ratings are distributed over the continuous latent variable representing anxiety.
In other words, the Female/Woman group is represented by a normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1, because Female/Woman is the reference level. The normal distribution representing Male/Man anxiety is shifted leftward, in a negative direction, by 0.33 units from the Female/Woman distribution. The Another Gender distribution is shifted rightward, in a positive direction, by 0.48 units.

round(coef(anx_fit2), 2)

      genderMale/Man genderAnother Gender 
               -0.33                 0.48 


With the following code, I compute each group‚Äôs normal distribution so that I can plot it. Concretely, I compute the probability density at each value of this latent continuous variable, adjusted for each gender group‚Äôs estimated mean.

anx_fit2_latent_normals <- tibble(
  Gender = factor(
    c('Female/Woman', 'Male/Man', 'Another Gender'),
    levels = c('Female/Woman', 'Male/Man', 'Another Gender')),
  mu = c(0, coef(anx_fit2))
) |>
  tidyr::expand(
    nesting(Gender, mu),
    x = seq(from = -3.5, to = 3.5, length.out = 200)
  ) |>
  mutate(
    d = dnorm(x, mean = mu, sd = 1)  # get dens at each x value for normal distrib with each row's mu
  )

head(anx_fit2_latent_normals)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 4
  Gender          mu     x        d
  <fct>        <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>
1 Female/Woman     0 -3.5  0.000873
2 Female/Woman     0 -3.46 0.000986
3 Female/Woman     0 -3.43 0.00111 
4 Female/Woman     0 -3.39 0.00126 
5 Female/Woman     0 -3.36 0.00141 
6 Female/Woman     0 -3.32 0.00159 



rating_labs <- tibble(
  x = c(-2.6, -1.4, -0.6, 0.1, 0.7, 1.5),
  d = c(0.57),
  labs = c('Rating:', 1:5),
  Gender = c('Female/Woman')
)

mm_mean <- anx_fit2$coefficients[['genderMale/Man']]
ag_mean <- anx_fit2$coefficients[['genderAnother Gender']]

anx_fit2_latent_normals |>
  ggplot(aes(x = x, y = d, fill = Gender)) +
  geom_area(position = 'identity', alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = anx_fit2$zeta, linetype = 'dotted', linewidth = 1) +
  geom_vline(linewidth = 1, xintercept = 0, colour = palette_gender[1]) +
  geom_vline(linewidth = 1, xintercept = mm_mean, colour = palette_gender[2]) +
  geom_vline(linewidth = 1, xintercept = ag_mean, colour = palette_gender[3]) +
  geom_text(data = rating_labs, aes(label = labs), family = 'Fira Sans', size = 8) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = palette_gender) +
  theme(
    axis.line.x.top = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x.top = element_blank(),
    legend.position = 'bottom'
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, breaks = NULL, limits = c(0, 0.6)) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    'Anxiety (assumed latent variable)', 
    breaks = -3:3,
    sec.axis = dup_axis(
      name = NULL,
      breaks = anx_fit2$zeta |> as.double(),
      labels = round(anx_fit2$zeta, 2)
    )) +
  geom_segment(aes(x= 0, y = 0.44, xend = mm_mean, yend = 0.44), linewidth = 1.5, arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.5,"cm")), colour = palette_gender[2]) +
  geom_label(aes(x = -0.33, y = 0.49), label = round(mm_mean, 2), fill = 'white', colour = palette_gender[2], family = 'Fira Sans', label.size = 1, size = 6) +
  geom_segment(aes(x= 0, y = 0.44, xend = ag_mean, yend = 0.44), linewidth = 1.5, arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.5,"cm")), colour = palette_gender[3]) +
  geom_label(aes(x = 0.48, y = 0.49), label = round(ag_mean, 2), fill = 'white', colour = palette_gender[3], family = 'Fira Sans', label.size = 1, size = 6) +
  NULL








The thresholds do not move. But shifting the normal distributions left and right changes how much probability density is allocated to each region, each rating.
I wrote the following function to compute the probability density between given thresholds for a normal distribution with given mean and standard deviation. (In these simple models, I‚Äôve kept the standard deviations always fixed at 1, but in principle, the standard deviation is also a parameter that can be fit to the data.)

get_prob_dens <- function(zetas, mu, sigma){
  # zetas: numeric vector, list of thresholds in Phi space (from polr model)
  # mu: numeric, mean of normal distribution
  # sigma: positive numeric, standard deviation of normal distribution
  
  # Back-transform thresholds into probability space according to location 
  # of shifted normal. Outcome contains cumulative probabilities.
  prob_spc_thresholds <- pnorm(zetas, mean = mu, sd = sigma)  
  
  # Add first and last elements to this cumsum so that successive differences 
  # come out right.
  probs_btwn_thresholds <- diff( c(`1` = 0, prob_spc_thresholds, 'x' = 1) )
  
  # Rename each element in the vector to the between-threshold sections.
  names(probs_btwn_thresholds) <- 1:length(probs_btwn_thresholds)
  
  probs_btwn_thresholds
}

Here‚Äôs one way to represent each group‚Äôs probability distribution individually, including those between-threshold probabilities.

fw_probs <- get_prob_dens(anx_fit2$zeta, 0, 1)

fw_prob_labs <- tibble(
  x = c(-2.6, -1.4, -0.56, 0.05, 0.66, 1.45),
  d = c(0.05),
  labs = c('Probability:', round(fw_probs, 2)),
  Gender = 'Female/Woman'
)

anx_fit2_latent_normals |>
  filter(Gender == 'Female/Woman') |>
  ggplot(aes(x = x, y = d)) +
  geom_area(position = 'identity', alpha = 0.5, fill = palette_gender[1]) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = anx_fit2$zeta, linetype = 'dotted') +
  geom_text(data = fw_prob_labs, aes(label = labs), family = 'Fira Sans') +
  geom_text(data = rating_labs, aes(y = d-0.15, label = labs), family = 'Fira Sans', size = 8) +
  theme(
    axis.line.x.top = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x.top = element_blank(),
    legend.position = 'none',
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, breaks = NULL) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    'Anxiety (assumed latent variable)', 
    breaks = -3:3,
    sec.axis = dup_axis(
      name = NULL,
      breaks = anx_fit2$zeta |> as.double(),
      labels = round(anx_fit2$zeta, 2)
    )) +
  ggtitle('Female/Woman') +
  NULL









mm_probs <- get_prob_dens(anx_fit2$zeta, mm_mean, 1)

mm_prob_labs <- tibble(
  x = c(-2.6, -1.4, -0.56, 0.05, 0.66, 1.3),
  d = c(0.05),
  labs = c('Probability:', round(mm_probs, 2)),
  Gender = 'Male/Man'
)

anx_fit2_latent_normals |>
  filter(Gender == 'Male/Man') |>
  ggplot(aes(x = x, y = d)) +
  geom_area(position = 'identity', alpha = 0.5, fill = palette_gender[2]) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = anx_fit2$zeta, linetype = 'dotted') +
  geom_text(data = mm_prob_labs, aes(label = labs), family = 'Fira Sans') +
  geom_text(data = rating_labs, aes(y = d-0.15, label = labs), family = 'Fira Sans', size = 8) +
  theme(
    axis.line.x.top = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x.top = element_blank(),
    legend.position = 'none',
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, breaks = NULL) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    'Anxiety (assumed latent variable)', 
    breaks = -3:3,
    sec.axis = dup_axis(
      name = NULL,
      breaks = anx_fit2$zeta |> as.double(),
      labels = round(anx_fit2$zeta, 2)
    )) +
  ggtitle('Male/Man') +
  NULL









ag_probs <- get_prob_dens(anx_fit2$zeta, ag_mean, 1)

ag_prob_labs <- tibble(
  x = c(-2.6, -1.2, -0.56, 0.05, 0.66, 1.7),
  d = c(0.05),
  labs = c('Probability:', round(ag_probs, 2)),
  Gender = 'Another Gender'
)

anx_fit2_latent_normals |>
  filter(Gender == 'Another Gender') |>
  ggplot(aes(x = x, y = d)) +
  geom_area(position = 'identity', alpha = 0.5, fill = palette_gender[3]) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = anx_fit2$zeta, linetype = 'dotted') +
  geom_text(data = ag_prob_labs, aes(label = labs), family = 'Fira Sans') +
  geom_text(data = rating_labs, aes(y = d-0.15, label = labs), family = 'Fira Sans', size = 8) +
  theme(
    axis.line.x.top = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x.top = element_blank(),
    legend.position = 'none',
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, breaks = NULL) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    'Anxiety (assumed latent variable)', 
    breaks = -3:3,
    sec.axis = dup_axis(
      name = NULL,
      breaks = anx_fit2$zeta |> as.double(),
      labels = round(anx_fit2$zeta, 2)
    )) +
  ggtitle('Another Gender') +
  NULL










Significance tests
polr() doesn‚Äôt provide p-values:

summary(anx_fit2)

Call:
polr(formula = rating ~ gender, data = anx, Hess = TRUE, method = "probit")

Coefficients:
                       Value Std. Error t value
genderMale/Man       -0.3280    0.03015 -10.880
genderAnother Gender  0.4846    0.11992   4.041

Intercepts:
    Value    Std. Error t value 
1|2  -0.9045   0.0169   -53.5402
2|3  -0.2246   0.0150   -14.9847
3|4   0.3318   0.0151    21.9158
4|5   0.9889   0.0176    56.2958

Residual Deviance: 26456.99 
AIC: 26468.99 


But it does give us t-values. So to know whether we can reject the null hypothesis (H0) that there‚Äôs no association between rating and gender, we can just treat the estimated t-values like z-scores and compare them to a standard normal distribution representing the H0.4

pnorm(abs(-10.880), lower.tail = FALSE) * 2

[1] 1.43563e-27

pnorm(abs(4.041), lower.tail = FALSE) * 2

[1] 5.322376e-05


For both parameters, the probability of observing a value that extreme or more extreme, given the H0 of no effect defined by the standard normal distribution, is less than 0.05. So we can reject the null hypotheses that

there‚Äôs no difference between Female/Woman and Male/Man ratings, and
there‚Äôs no difference between Female/Woman and Another Gender ratings.
